reviews.review_text: TLDR: This game is great, there is so many solid reasons to give it a recommendation. The most important one being that this is literally a AAA game standard at a B game price. It still feels like a steal even if you buy it right now at full price.  Edit: Also, this game should be named game of the year by reviewers.  Before review, I'll talk about some of the critisim I saw in others' reviews:  1)  Poor graphics .  Seriously, do me a favor and just down-rate any review you see that complains about this. Just go compare the screenshots of this game from community hub with other games, even the triple-A games. This game has beautiful graphics comparable to other much more expensive titles. Not to say that this game is the pinnacle of gaming graphcis but there's very little to complain about if you're being honest with yourself.  2)  Frustrating inventory full of junk .  To be honest, inventory management aren't well designed and took about 10-15% of my gaming time. Do keep this in mind if you don't like to plan or look at fine prints of a game. You can play the game at a lower difficulty setting and completely ignore this portion of the game if you hate inventory management or looking through a list of available upgrades.  3)  Game difficulty .  The difficulty descriptions are detailed when starting new game so much so they even give the exact % increase in received damage, enemy HP and exp gained. But if you haven't started playing I highly recommend you to play this game near the highest difficulty level. Normal feels like easy and Hard doesn't feel hard. Insanity level 1 feels more like somewhere between normal and hard of a typical game. Keep this in mind when you start a new game. If you like a challenge just keep changing difficulty level to the highest one available based on your character level. Only at insanity level 4 did I feel like the game is at hard core mode of a typical game.  4)  Bad story . As most story and artisitic appreciation goes, this is very subjective. Shadow Warrior 2013 wins in terms of the raw feel it deliveries. In particular the humor and x factor if that's even a thing. And Shadow Warrior 2013 has a stronger ending. But due to all the added dimensions of the story in SW2 I feel that the story here is more rich and there's alot more lore building. There's alot of small notes you can find and collect and read when the game ends. Its nothing as ground breaking as Resident Evil's 'Fever gone but itchy. Hungry and eat doggy food. Itchy Itchy Scott came. Ugly face so killed him. Tasty.'. But to be fair they are interesting to read anyway. Oh and SW2 ending suck.  5)  Frustrating element system . There are 2 sets of element. If enemy is immune to poison, it is weak to electric and vise versa. If enemy is immune to fire, it is weak to ice and vise versa. Very simple mechanics and yet people feel it keeps them from enjoying the game. I feel its interesting and prevents gamers from bulldozing through the game mindlessly. So, I like it.  6)  Boring fetch quests . The quests actually adds abit of story and conversation between Lo Wang and NPCs so its not all boring. Honestly, you can literally rush through the level without fighting and finish the quest quite quickly. Problem solved. You know a complaint is stupid if its solution is one only sentence and doesn't require any sacrifice of any sort. Also, no idea why such a subjective opinion get repeated in the exact same phrasing so many times. Feels almost like its the same guy who bought many copies of the game just to lower the rating of this game to below 90%.  7)  Game gets old fast . Another stupid complaint. The game is actually very interesting due to high customizability to gamer's perferences. See point '8' of my review of this game below and you'll see why.   Before I go ahead and review this game, I'll just go right ahead and mention the following:  1)  Preorder discount .  You get 10% upfront for pre-order or 20% if you already own the previous game. I'll be lying if I said it didn't affect my impression of this game and their dev team and management. Doing so not only win fans' hearts, it also kinda shows how they're not here for the money. Also reminds me of some of the cool people I've met in my life who I wouldn't mind buying them drinks every once in awhile.  2)  Lack of bug and optimization issues .  Sounds like a weird thing to mention except when you look at recent releases like Mafia 3 and Dishonored 2 etc. Oh, and the not so recent Arkham Knight. I basically feel its quite shameless to release games in broken condition and it seems to be a common trend these days.  In short, looking beyond the game itself. These guys are a good bunch of fellows who did their job well and aren't here just to make money. Not say that they don't wish to profit, but obviously they don't do so by doing questionable things like selling out on people's trust in them.  Wow, I've already said so much about this game I'm feel sleepy. Anyway, here comes the review:  1) This game has a 89% rating. So, if you're not picky as hell there's a good chance you'll enjoy youself playing this game.  2) Good graphcis.  3) Fast pace awesome action game.  4)  Better than Doom 2016 .  Yup, your eyes aren't playing tricks. I'm going to go ahead and say that this game is so good that I feel that its better than Doom. Down rate this review if you disagree but this is how I feel honestly. From story to game design to environment design to just how the game generally feels.  5) Good story. But bad ending.  6) Good music. I mean like seriously good. But you may need the Deluxe Upgrade to enjoy it fully.  7) Good value for money. This is literally a AAA game at a B game price. Definitely must buy.  8) Notable improvements above Shadow Warrior 2013.  8a) Ammunition used to be insufficient at high difficulty due to high enemy HP. Less of an issue now. Basically you are not forced to use melee weapon at high difficulty levels.  8b) Interest factor. Getting new weapon, skill etc constantly allowed me to constantly enjoy the game in a new light.  8c) Customizability. You can spec your character to DPS Build (High Crit Change and Dmg Bonus), Tank Build (Dmg resist and HP), Invisibility High Dmg Build (Raw Damage without Crit), High Mobility Build etc etc. You can abuse the mechanics of the game in a very forcus specific way using upgrades and they are fun in their own way. Btw, high dps means you can hack and slash and make use of high DPS. Invis however means you have to hit enemies one hit at a time as invisibility bonnus damage only applies for one attack and then you will have to go invis again so Crit chance and damage doesn't apply with consistency here.  8d) Free Roam. I like how I can go back to stages I've completed before.  8e) I know how many people say its like Diablo or Borderlands but is that necessarily bad Subjective if you ask me.  8f) Also the elemental system. I think I find it fun. I like how I can poison and burn enemies to death, freeze or paralyse enemies with ice or electricity. I like especially how corpse of poisoned enemies explodes and poisons + damage other enemies near them. Fun to see a chain of explosions. Disagree if you like, then just ignore this point as an improvement.  8g) No need to find all secrets for achievement. I think you only need to find about 70-80% to unlock achievement which I think is much more reasonable than having to find them all.  9)  Photo Mode . I love how I can take photos of scenic views when I see one. Might even say the whole gaming experience feels like a vacation in Lo Wang's world.  10)  Co-op  Didn't actually try. Seems like there's a friendlist and a public mode.  So, to conclude just buy the game already. I'm sure its obvious that you will very likely enjoy it and find every dollar spent well worth it.

(updated)  I liked the 2013 Shadow Warrior a lot. I think this game is just as good, if not a little bit better.  Possible Spoilers:  Pros:  - LOT of new weapons. I stopped counting after 20. - Duel wielding for a lot of weapons. - Duel wielding katanas! (I feel just like Deadpool!) - Nice game play. - Same old smart mouth Wang. - Stan Bush intro! - The game doesn't strip everything away from you that you earned in Shadow Warrior. You get to keep your chi powers (to an extent). Weapons, clearly, are reset, but you get a lot. - New enemies.  - Old enemies with improved graphics! - I believe that Lo Wang has schizophrenia! - The in-game descriptions of things are still just as funny. - A lot of the old characters make an appearance.  - Hoji's grave. - Remember the giant horse-eagle armored guy you had to fight? You get to see his armor again! Also, he's in the story.  - The story is pretty good. Not as simple as: 'get a sword. Get another sword. Get a third sword. Fight and try to kill former boss. Watch friend die. Kill friend's ♥♥♥♥♥♥ brother.'  Meh: It reminds me of Dragon Age 2 with how you have a base to return to that kinda serves as an HQ. But unlike Dragon Age 2, it doesn't SUCK. At all.   Cons: - The cutscenes are a bit janky. You start out in one spot then warp over to another. They didn't attempt to make them smooth like the last game. - It feels like everyone betrays you in this game! The only person I'm loyal to is the little voice inside my head... Kinda like in the 2013 Shadow Warrior actually... I can only take so many betrayals before it starts to feel like Knights of the Old Republic 2: The Sith Lords with Darth Traya is running the show.  This is a good game. As of this review, I would highly suggest it. So far, I think it's better than the 2013 version they did.

I haven't followed the Shadow Warrior series very much. I didn't play the last game (the demo didn't impress me too much), and I had not played the original DOS game either, so I was coming into this with no real expectations (other than a certainty that this couldnt be as fast and smooth as the recent DOOM).   Well, suffice to say, Shadow Warrior 2 has proven to be a pleasant surprise indeed.   A lot of people are comparing this game to Borderlands, Diablo and even the aformentioned DOOM reboot. Personally, I think a better comparision would be Star Wars Jedi Knight: Dark Forces 2. Like that game, you'll be fighting with three primary toolkits; magic (called Chi here), guns and melee weapons. Also like Dark Forces 2, melee combat uses movement combinations to dictate the type of attack you unless (though it is far more advanced here). Add to this the sprawling and often vertical design to the levels , its hard to think of this as anything short of a spiritual successor to that Lucas Arts classic.  Where this game does differ from Dark Forces is in its speed and violence. This game is FAST, rivaling (and occassionally suprassing) the pace of DOOM 2016. Combat is so hectic that you'll end up resorting to button mashing in a panic for the first few levels. This works for a while, just long enough to make you doubt the depth and quality of the games systems, but after a few missions, you'll gain a deeper understanding of how to control both your movement and sword to unleash more deliberate attacks and manouvers. Just in time too, because button mashing absolutly stops being viable once the training wheels are off, and the enemy numbers start going through the roof (and the levels get bigger).   Once you get the hang of it and have upgraded both your Chi and arsenal, each battle turns into a strangely ordered chaos. Particles fire off every which way as you leap, zip and slash your way into the hordes of monstrosities. The pace and flavor of these fights almost makes you feel like you're starring in your very own action anime', amidst some fantastic environments that range from neo-tokyo style dystopias to warped japanese villages. However, for how beautiful these areas look, they are also where the game starts to stumble.   The game is supposed to have semi-proceduraly generated levels, though I couldn't tell you if it had any real effect. Areas are very clearly recycled multiple times over, leading to each zone eventually feeling inconsequential. The game itself is still so much fun that this becomes little more than a small annoyance, but it is one I do hope the devs will address either with patches or expansions/ DLC's. Less easy to ignore is the use of invisible walls and clunky nature of the mantling system. To put it bluntly; as much fun as dashing and jumping is, it is NOT as smooth and cleanly executed as in DOOM. Several times I'd try to catch onto a rooftop that was well within range, to no avail. Some roofs would keep pushing me off as if I had hit an invisible border, and at least once I managed to walk on top of a level because I had jumped over some invisible barrier. Granted, this last one only happened once, but the fact that it was possible at all is somewhat odd.   Speaking of bugs; there was also a funny instance where a boss battle had began, but I had accidently back peddled too far back before the lockdown door could close, thus creating an impassible barrier between the enemy and myself, leaving us to awkwardly stare at the door and get nowhere.    Those are about the only real issues I had though. The plot- such as it is- is okay, niether great nor awful. It's chuckle worthy now and again, with a couple of laugh out loud segments, but the meat of the game is in the fights, not its dialogue or plot. Speaking of which; some reviewers online have complained about the humour being overly juvinile and falling flat. I myself am not generally a fan of crass humor, but I didn't find anything so off putting here. Many people have commented that the central joke is '♥♥♥♥♥', but honestly, I felt more like the joke was that Lo Wang isnt as funny as he thinks he is. Certainly, the characters he's surrounded by are only barely tollerating his antics, which more often than not does make for some funny scenes.   Anyhow, all in all; Shadow Warrior 2 was a TON of fun. If you're coming from DOOM, this is an obvious next step. If you were a fan of Jedi Knight: Dark Forces 2, this should be a no-brainer.

- Review written at the state of the game on the 23rd of October 2016. -  Fun, lots of fun, but a little easy and unpolished, and gets repetitive.   Not a lot of replay value.   If you'd like a game thats a bit of a throwback to the old Duke Nukem/Doom style 90's shoot-em-ups, this game has a lot of oldschool play feel (I can't remember the last time I pushed up to #8 to change weapons?!)   = The Good =  - Fast fun, energetic action play - Quippy funny dialogue (if you have a 13 year old male sense of humour like me, otherwise you'll hate it) - Interesting levels that each have a different feel to them (until you find you've played the same one 3 times with a slightly different objective) - Cool weapons, and the ability to slot upgrades into them (until you realise they didn't really put that much effort into the upgrade system and its fairly randomised) - Decent melee combat (whole game with melee challenge anyone?) - Interesting story and characters  = The Bad = - After the first two hours of play you'll start to realise that the game is actually fairly repetitive in its playstyle.  - The minimap makes the game TOO EASY. It could have been interesting if I had to find my way through levels but you just follow the little 'auto direction' thingy in the map and you get to your objective. So you don't really explore the level at all, and a lot of work was put into the design if you look at them.  - Even if you had to search for loot- the loot system doesn't really reward exploration anyway. Loot drops in level seem completely randomised If they had specific hidden upgrades you had to search for that gave unique rewards, exploring the level would be much more interesting. - Your shift key will be mashed to bits. The 'dash' aspect makes the game way too easy. You can kite enemies forever, until you run out of space to run into, which is never. Get hurt, press shift a few times and run away, heal up off chi, return and fight. Repeat. I heard there used to be a limit to how often you could use it like an endurance bar, what happened to that? - Although the melee system is fun, having 3 special attacks in a way is a bit limiting. Some sort of fancy WASD combos with slashes could have made it a bit more interesting. Parrying is somewhat worthless. - Enemies have no weak points, you just shoot/slash at them till they die, doesn't matter if you hit them head foot or whatever, doesn't matter, there's no damage different. Same for bosses.   Summary -  - After 15 hours, I finished the game on the second most hardest difficulty. I think i died about 5 times, but you become way too strong for the enemies toward the end of the game. It really becomes more about how much fun you can have killing them.  - No intention to play further, there's no point. I don't think I'll gain anything by doing it in the hardest mode. There's nothing more to do in it, I did multiplayer for a bit with my friends, but it's the same thing, just more enemies.   Can only recommend if you want to pay the price for about 15 hours worth of play. Overall, it's fun. But I don't care about the money to afford it that much, however, you might not want to shell out for it.

Incredibly fun and very funny. Very similar to Borderlands gameplay - Kill stuff, loot, quest, rinse & repeat on a new difficulty.  The protagonist's dialogue is without a doubt one of the most hilariously-written scripts I've played in 30 years. I've lost count of the number of games that try to be funny but fall cringingly short. Shadow Warrior 2 doesn't just hit the mark, it gives it a middle finger.  Pros:    Extremely funny    Excellent shoot-em-up gameplay    Engaging quests and cutscenes   Cons:    Multiplayer feels tacked-on. No chat. No voice. No way to kick troublesome/AFK players as the host, and only one way to filter the dozens or even hundreds of games in the server browser - difficulty. No 'ping' visibility, which means many joined games are brutally laggy to the point of being unplayable.     Only one 'class' - the protagonist himself, although amulets, gems, and skills provide for at least 2 major classes - Melee or Ranged. To a lesser degree, minor sub-classes are possible with very specific gems and skills - Healer and Tank. A coop gem allows for a heal aura or 'direct damage' healing, and a tank would just stock up on damage resist and health. This is only recommended for coordinated teams, though, since going any route other than pure DPS will take its toll in singleplayer. This game was my most anticipated title of the year. The first one blew me away, and I couldn't believe it didn't get more attention for being so visually spectacular and fun (first person melee combat is rarely good or visceral in the way that SW2013 is). The sequel is good, but they throw out the linear story-based game with a simple ability/weapon upgrade system in favor of a mission-based shooter that feels more like Borderlands than anything else. Wang is still funny, the environments and shadows still look best in class, and the gun and swordplay are still super satisfying, but the pacing is wrong. Stopping to loot, and spending a lot of time in menus modifying weapons and equipping new ones feels more monotonous than it should, and turns it into something more reminiscent of Borderlands than SW2013. They might've gone too far in a few places, here.  Seems like a lot of people had the same issues. I kind of wish they had just stuck to their guns and given us more of the same type of game the 2013 version was. You can see what FWH was going for pretty clearly; they wanted to include a ton of weapon variation that the 2013 system just wouldn't have allowed for (that game played more like an old school shooter where there's x # of total guns and once you have them all that's it). Including claws or dual swords wouldn't have been easy to do unless they were purely a cosmetic change. But the benefits of having a bunch of extra weapons were outweighed in my opinion by the tedium of equipping and socketing them.  The last problem I had with the game was the sidekick character. Kamiko just doesn't have the same impact or rapport with Wang/the player that Hoji did. Hoji's story in the 2013 game was surprisingly poignant, and by the end of a game that was supposed to be about murdering the ♥♥♥♥ out of demons as a man whose name is a euphemism for ♥♥♥♥♥ shouting puns about it every few minutes, I was actually emotionally invested. Hoji was a friend. Kamiko clearly detests Wang until like, 2 or 3 missions from the end, when she kind of has a make-or-break moment of 'oh ♥♥♥♥, this guy holds my fate in his hands I need to stop being such a ♥♥♥♥ to him.' It's abrupt, it doesn't work for me, and I didn't care about her at all.   Shadow Warrior 2 is still worth a look to anyone interested. Even with all the flaws, the gunplay and visuals are so good I still rate it an 8/10 at least. But I would highly recommend newcomers trying the 2013 game first. It's a better, more compact experience, and regularly goes on sale for like $5. The writing is better in that game and doesn't try so hard to recapture bottled lightning.

The upgrade system is a bit too overwhelming as well and should be toned down, you get too many powerups all the time and it's a lot to manage (not a biggie for me though).  Once the game opens up properly a few missions later though, it gets really fun. I'd really like to see SS4 made in a similar style as it feels very innovative.

Couple of things that Im not so crazy about so far: (And yes Im aware that Wang learned these things prior in SW) Right off the bat you can heal yourself. Let me start by saying that I'm not really that much of a shooter fan, but I did love the first game and I'm also a fan of co-op stuff like Left 4 Dead and Borderlands.   That being said, this game in its current form just isn't a very good sequel to Shadow Warrior (2013) and not a very good loot-based co-op shooter either.  The main problem I think is that the game is hurt by too much randonmess: rather than a tightly crafted and challenging corridor shooter, you get a a game in which nearly everything is random and as a result of that, more often than not just not very compelling.  Despite of the random nature, pretty much every fight and every level feels exactly the same, and apart from very basic tactics regarding various elemental weapons, there just isn't too much to most of the fights - sure, they can be fun and fast and frantic, but the majority ends up feeling far too easy and far too long. This is made worse by the fact that especially in co-op dying rarely feels like it matters and it's far too easy to use cheesy kiting techniques.   On top of that, exploring the levels just isn't very much fun since all they will ever offer is more of the same, and the game throws so much and such poor loot at you that running around collecting everything is rather pointless - pretty much all the cool stuff is obtained automatically or very easily found by killing the mini-bosses and the endless slew of weapons mods that you get is more of a chore to sift through (using a horrible interface) than something to get excited about. This is probaby the first game ever, also, in which low level common or rare upgrades are often better than ultra expensive and and rare legendary upgrades, further adding to the sense of pointlessness of it all.   And to top it all of, the system with a quest hub and numerous fetch quests adds very little to a game of this type, other than constantly keeping you out of the action with endless loading screens and boring cutscenes. I simply started skipping them halfway through.  I'm not ruling out the possiblity that this game can be ultimately saved by a gigantic patch that overhauls the loot system into something meaningful and rewarding, but even then I feel that the repetitive and random nature of this game will not lead to something memorable. It's OK to play in short bursts if you just want to have something colorful to look at without having to think to much, but it feels far to much like busywork to be compelling for long periods of time.

This is not as good as the previous game. It feels unpolished, incomplete. Especially given the previous game. They went more Borderlands style with this one, looter shooter, only it's lacking some elements that made that work. The loot in this comes not from weapons, but from gems to slot into said weapons. The problem with that is that most of these gems are just stat boosts. A slight increase in a stat or two, and the 'better' ones all come with a drawback. There ARE some elemental ones, but again, they get slightly better as the game progresses, that's it. The only ones that are actually good are there are a few that actually change the behavior of the weapons. IMHO the system would be better with only those gems, and only one slot per weapon. AND NO ♥♥♥♥ING ELEMENTS. Seriously, I hate those.  The recent patch 1.1.3.0 only made a few things worse. And illustrates that the game is still, effectively, in beta. They've been asking the community what they want to improve, and using that to balance the game... slightly. They nerfed a couple things that were admittedly overpowered, but they also reduced the effectiveness of some things that weren't that powerful. And on top of that they increased the difficulty of enemies, AND reduced the amount of skills players can get. Enemies can now spawn resistant to everything just by the nature of having so many modifiers put on them in higher difficulties. Combine that with removing one of the major reasons to even bother with New Game+ - that being gaining skill points from repeating missions (you only get the skill points once now, no matter how many replays), and it just feels like they're poking blindingly and hoping the game will eventually balance out.  There's a lot of base weapons in the game, more than 70. You won't use most of them. I don't even really like the flow of combat in this one versus the previous game. The previous game was quick, responsive, and you could do a lot with combinations of movement keys. Double tapping a direction to prepare spells etc. The new one puts them on different buttons, which just adds to the complexity of the controls. And not in a good way. Controllers are not able to be freely customized either. This makes this game more complex, needlessly so. The levels as well are pieced together procedurally generated to add some randomness. However, the pieces do NOT always fit together well, creating a lot of seams and places where you could jump out of the map entirely, or get stuck.  Even the story feel like a bit of a rehash, and a let down, from the previous game. The previous game's was very interesting, and kept me sucked in. This one feels disjointed, not helped by the fact that there are side missions. The cut scenes as well are VERY badly animated. Like they are filled with placeholder animation, with wild, exaggerated movements that in no way match up with what is going on. It looks absolutely awful.  All in all... no. I don't recommend this. Maybe if they fix it, but this game right now feels like Early Access... and I don't see it actually ever being completed.

Note, I played the game on Hardcore mode from the get-go here. So these comments are from the perspective of only the hardest difficulty level, on single player scaling.  Pros:  +Runs like a charm, no FPS drops even during intense combat. (This is on a mid-high end rig)  +Funny dialogue that only occasionally falls flat. Kind of like a ♥♥♥♥♥.  +Diverse array of weapons to use and unlock.  +Great looking levels.  +Fairly diverse array of creatures to mutilate.  +Great viceral feedback from melee weapons.  +Dashing feels good, and helps traverse boring open space quickly.   Cons:  -Awful level design. Tons of backtracking through empty areas, and tons of 'open areas' to 'explore', that 99% of the time have nothing of interest. Not even enemies to fight. The game wants you to parkour, but gives you almost no tools to do so. Only certain ledges can be grabbed. You find yourself running around a lot looking for ways to move toward the objective. Very UN-ninja like.  -Very little variation in fights. All the monsters behave the same. Ranged dudes kick you away when you get close, and melee dudes try and keep their blades in your wang at all times. No matter what type of creature they're skinned as, this remains true of all enemies.  -The chi system is tedious to manage. You usually only have the option of using and focusing on a single skill. Even with maxed out regen/pool size cards. This will almost exclusively be the heal, since most elite/special enemies have a debuff aura that stacks with each element type, and force you to constantly spam the heal button to remove them since they'll kill you in 3 seconds if you ignore them.  -Ammunition starvation & Bullet Sponge Enemies. Ammunition drops are FAR too scarse in the hardcore difficulty. You mag dump the entire ammo pool of every weapon type into 3 bullet sponge enemies, then have to use the chain saw or katana for the rest of the map until you pick up 10 shotgun shells per every 10 enemies you defeat. Gets tedious very quickly.  -Completely unnecessary Borderlands style stat management / Diablo style gem system. Slows down the action, and forces you to stop and switch mods when certain immune enemies show up. Biggest downside to this though is the ridiculous amount of low level mods you will pick up that clog your inventory. There is no effective way to quick sell mods below a certain level. You need to manually mark every single of of them as 'junk' and then sell them to a vendor. It's tedious. The mods also sell for virtually nothing. Even the 'legendary' rank mods.  -Loot gathering. I shouldn't need to stop on top of dead dudes and mash 'E' to gather book drops. It slows down the action, and makes me have to back track after kiting enemies after long fights that usually take 5-15 mins due to the bullet sponginess of enemies.  -Sprinting. When you're spamming dash constantly, sprinting doesn't really do anything. Either make Wang always run at the sprint speed, or remove it altogether. It's tedious to manage.  -Melee skill charging. Why the hell does it take 5+ seconds to fully charge a melee stab/spin attack? Slows down the action, and makes you need to kite for an unnecessary period of time.    I'm sure some of these things are influenced by having 1-2 more players. However, the bullet sponge enemies that aren't bosses are ridiculous. I shouldn't have to chain saw into a Yakuza's chest for literally 120 seconds with a min/maxed fire damage warrrsaw on enemies that are weak to fire. Even on the hardest difficulty. Make the AI smarter, or have more abilities/better weapons. Don't just tack on more HP and call it a day.  Steam really needs a 'mixed' option for recommending games. This game is perilously close to thumbs down territory. But, it's fun enough if you can look past the more tedious portions of the game mechanics.  If you're looking for a shorter, less open Borderlands with more ♥♥♥♥ jokes. This is your game. If you're looking for a non-stop slasher/action shooter - pass on this game, or play it only on the lowest difficulty setting.

-- PROS --  + The loot system is really great. You find your weapons from special bosses (marked as a skull on your map), or occasionally from chests (potentially from other monsters, but I think I've only seen that once). You then find upgrades for your weapons, which is the loot that largely drops throughout the game modes. The weapons have set stats, but the upgrades do not, so that is what you farm for. They give you a lot of loot, so you have a lot of chances to find something valuable. The highest rarity drops at frequent enough intervals to keep you from getting frustrated, but not so often that they rain from the sky.   + The shops are actually done properly. You can find real hidden gems in there, and as soon as you progress through the story enough you can find some really great high level upgrades. At the moment I am posting this review...you can do something pretty cheesy... get to the end of your first playthrough (after finishing the final boss), then bump up your difficulty to the highest setting. Go back into your game and visit the shops. There will be higher level gear in there than what you should be getting (at least that's how it worked for me).  + The combat is a blast! I dislike first person shooters usually (mostly because they give me headaches, but also because I suck at fast paced shooting). This game is great because they have a very viable melee combat system. In fact, right now it's more viable to be melee than it is to use guns (a common complaint that will at some point be fixed, I presume). My favorite weapon is a chainsaw, because the melee skills feel much more pleasant with that weapon than with any other type. My boyfriend plays this game with me, and he solely uses guns while I solely use melee. It works out very well for us, and he loves the gun combat.  +/- The humor...lots of sexual inneundos (which is a negative for me - I don't like this style of 'funny' - but a positive to others, and is trademark to this series). But the game did keep me laughing (mostly AT it). There are a lot of genetalia jokes, so enter at your own risk. There are also Fortune Cookies which are really cute and usually have a funny message.  + The environments are randomly generated, which I like.  -- CONS --  - The story... I'm not going to go into detail (there are plenty of reviews that do that for you already), but the story left me wanting. The ending in particular left me with a WTF look on my face. I was really angry about the end cutscene. Anyways, if you take out the humor, which is in 75%+ of the questline, you're left with a very lackluster story.   - Ammo can be hard to find. If you don't like switching weapon types (because there's a chance you'll run out of ammo of a certain type), you won't enjoy this game as much. There are skills that help combat this. On that same note, you also need to have elemental weapons set up and a physical weapon. There are enemies that are completely immune or just resistant to certain types of damage. There is a lot of weapon switching. I personally don't like to switch weapons, so I just set up my melee to physical, have one back up elemental melee weapon in case of a physical-immune enemy, and then power house through Physical Resistance enemies with my main physical melee weapon. I have only elemental range weapons, which I primarily use for big story bosses where melee can be rough.  - Crafting is a waste of time and money. You'd rather just reset the shop and hope to get lucky. This might be changed eventually.  Overall, this is a really fun game! The positives far outweigh the negatives. This is worth a purchase, in my opinion. The devs patch frequently and balance the game, so you'll see a lot of changes throughout the upcoming months.   Note: If you intend to play this game ONLY cooperatively, I do not recommend this game YET. I would wait a few patches for them to clean it up before getting into it. The experience for me was...very lackluster and incredibly frustrating. And there were changes in patches that completely infuriated me. I wish I had waited to play this game and not bought it Day One.  -- My COOP Experience --  My boyfriend hosts. We go through the entire playthrough, all the way to the end. The entire time, my progress did not not save in my story (this is an intended feature). So, if I wanted to play my own game without him, I would have to start all over again from the beginning. It is absolutely a HUGE waste of time to go through your first playthrough if you have already gone through it once cooperatively, which I'll explain in a moment.  Throughout that playthrough, I missed out on a few skills that were rewarded from quests (perhaps a bug, I received some skills, but not all of them). At a certain point in the story the shops reset and get great loot. At this point, the player that does not host (probably due to the fact that your own story progress does not save, so it thinks you shouldn't have access to these shops), you cannot talk to shops. This means you cannot buy ammo (which can be scarce, especially if you don't hunt down chests). This means you cannot buy any skills. This means you cannot buy any weapons that are added to the shops in the late game. This means you cannot sell anything. You cannot buy anything (and the shops have great loot sometimes). This is a bug, and presumably will be fixed. But for my experience on day one...this SUCKS.   Also, when crafting is unlocked for the host, it is not also unlocked for the coop player. So, you'll need to go through the first few hours of the game on your own save game, where you won't get anything for your time other than low level upgrades and some XP and gold. Then if you wanted to craft you could. I'm not sure if this unlocks the crafting in coop or not (I haven't tested it), but if it doesn't, you can always just go into your own game when you want to craft. But, crafting sucks in this game, so don't do it.   And the coop specific performance issues...oh gosh...CONSTANT disconnects from the server (even with good internet connection). Constant huge frame rate dips... every patch improves these things. But it still isn't what it should be.  So, since I was missing a handful of great things from not hosting myself... I was frustrated and quit the game. A few patches roll out, and now they have added these Orbs. You get them from quests after your first playthrough (basically to give you a reason to go through different playthroughs). They will help you boost the stats on a chosen weapon with the next patch. But for now you can just collect them. We think 'let's play Shadow Warrior 2 again and horde some resources for the next patch!'   We launch the game, and since I'm still frustrated with missing out on skills (that are actually useful), I decide to host. We go through a few quests...and then I realize that I'm not getting any orbs. Because, duh, the game thinks this is my first playthrough...meanwhile, the host from my last playthrough is getting a lot of them. Since I've already done these quests once, I don't get any rewards from them other than the ones that bugged out. Fantastic. So, I get to go through this entire playthrough, really only to gain XP (there is a cap at some point, which I haven't hit yet), gold, and some very rare upgrades. Because, as I said, the upgrades are tied to story progression. I go through most of the playthrough finding really garbage loot, with nothing useful in shops until the second half of the game. That entire first half I find maybe one upgrade that I ended up equipping. But, hey, at least I could pick up the skills that I should have gotten already and purchase the weapons that I should have already been able to buy!   Frustrating and a huge waste of 13hrs to go through that playthrough. It's annoying that you are penalized for not hosting, even though you have completed every quest once! Pros     *  Lots of meat and procedural gore  *  Very satisfying swordplay and chainsaw weapons  *  Fast and responsive movement system  *  Freedom of movement  *  70 unique weapons to choose from to suit your playstyle  *  Great soundtrack (especially title screen theme)  *  Really cool visuals (enviroments and PostFX) and weather effects  *  Runs really good even on not that powerful hardware (except setups with dual-core CPUs)  *  Photo mode  *  No Denuvo    Cons     *  Stats and level based gameplay, especially on harder difficulty modes  *  Borderalnds-style FPS and loot system (for some players all of this and all that is below can be a huge departure from the first game and a very serious flaw)  *  Bullet sponge enemies (not regular mobs that you can kill in 1-2 sec) with weakness to various elements (can be very annoying, aggravating, dull and tedious)  *  Weapon upgrade system (you can't ignore it and it ruins pacing on harder difficulty modes cuz you constantly need to upgrade weapons to make bullet sponge enemies less annoying, dull and tedious)  *  Useless and needless crafting system, hub and shops (gems and stuff like that - just don't buy anything except weapons, skills and ammo)  *  Levels can be very similar to one another (they are procedurally generated)  *  Semi-openworld structure of levels (for some players it can be boring to wander around on a big map to look for action, enemies to fight, mission objectives etc.)  *  Side quests and stuff like that (most of them are fetch quests)  *  Really bad character models (personal nitpicking, but for F's sake Flying Wild Hog, it's 2016!)  *  Co-op    Overall score:     7,5  /10  If you think that the negatives is not a bad thing - buy this game, if not - stay as far away or wait for a sale. Shadow Warrior 2 is an explosion of fun, blood, guts, guns, blades and mobility. A ridiculously over-the-top massacre with the sole purpose of being enjoyable. Stuff explodes and breaks apart everywhere all the time as blood and viscera sprays all over the place and there's this juvenile sense of fun in it. It has a strong 90s feel in those areas. It's a kind of a game that has tons of shortcomings but I just didn't care and enjoyed myself all the way through. The slaughterfest that it offers is just really satisfying. Not to mention the game looks absolutely stunning.  With that said, the open nature of the game with the overworld map, side quests, loot and leveling is a double edged sword. It has potential but feels subpar and rushed. The non-combat areas are pretty lifeless and dull, especially when compared to the lore that's incredibly abundant in the game. You're constantly drowning in upgrade gems that kind of blend together too much and it's easy to lose track of your stuff. The semi-random levels do not have a whole lot of pieces to offer so you're gonna see the same bits over and over in seemingly different parts of the world and, to be perfectly honest, the diversity of the environments is not as high as in the SW'13. The game has a decent amount of content but the story lacks any kind of meaningful conclusion.  Compared to the previous game though, it has a much better feel to the combat. The enemies are no longer bullet sponges that take forever to kill (might still be the case on higher difficulty levels). Guns are, for the first time in a FWG game, actually fun to use and as far as melee goes, watching enemies getting sliced into bloody pieces is as fun as always. Especially the movement is a huge step up from SW'13. No more pointless stamina bars: you've got an infinite sprint, double jump, dash and ZERO fall damage. That let's you just glide and fly through the environments like a badass ninja should be able to.  I think the best way to go about it is to approach this game as a stress reliever and stick to Easy/Normal. Do not overthink it, sit back, laugh at cringe-worthy jokes and enjoy the carnage.

It's hard not to feel like a badass when you take on 15 enemies and systematically hack, shoot and blast them to pieces. The story is over the top and ridiculous as the gameplay but there is a certain amount of depth and dialogue from the characters especially in regards to your traveling companion. The graphics are nice; again, it's not the Witcher 3 and there are some areas of clipping and a few bugs here and there but overall it's very easy on the eyes especially when you're flying through mounds of bloody piles. I'd recommend this game any day. It's fun for a twenty minute mission or a two hour slog- I've been playing for around 9 hours now and am only about 20% complete (side quests included) and there's enough content here to keep me going for a long time. Pick it up even if you're not particularly a fan of the genre (I wasn't really before playing it). It'll grow on you over time. Edit: Upon completing the game, I loved it even more. Simple as that. Not to give anything away but there will definitely be a sequel. Great to see and feel from the producers.  Chop-chop motherf*ckers. Get hacking.

Pros  +Very good graphics, weapon models, and animations. +Amazing soundtrack. +Hillarious dialogue. +Interesting story (up until the ending, anyways). +Large variety of weapons to choose from to meet your enemy slaughtering needs. +Pretty good RPG aspects to improve certain parts of your character as you progress. +Weapons feel impactful as you slice, dice, and explode your way through groups of enemies. +Loot upgrades allow you to make your weapons even stronger, allowing you to kill even more enemies faster. +Large maps to explore to find chests, secrets, or side bossess. +Maps are diverse enough to not cause visual burnout. +Good enemy variety throughout the levels. +Decently challenging, however becomes a little too easy once you get certain weapons and skills. +Variety of skill upgrades allow you to choose the way that you play, with the option to reset at any point in the hub world.  Cons  -Multiplayer feels tacked on. Inviting friends is a chore, lack of in game communication method, co-op specific bugs, story progress made while playing co-op will not transfer over to your solo game, some enemies (such as the bunny lord) do not drop loot for clients, some quest rewards are given to the host only (such as the 'Like the Wind' skill), requires insanely good connection from both the clients and the host in order to not experience lag, unable to change game from public to invite only (or even from single player to multi player) once you have launched the game, some achievements do not track properly during co op (such as the 50 vanish kills), chests are opened locally and not globally so every player has to open their own chests, and only the host can progress the quests forward. -Framerate drops in later areas of the game when 5+ superior or elite enemies are on screen. I don't have the perfect computer, but sometimes my FPS would drop to below 40 when fighting groups of superiors. I would also occassionally encounter freezing for brief seconds when speeding through an area and hitting a checkpoint. -Some of the weapons are way too underpowered (such as the infinite ammo SMG) and other weapons are far too strong (such as the Arm of Orochi). I would have preferred having a more balanced variety of weapons so I don't have to ask myself towards the end of the game 'Why am I even using this weapon?' -Too many upgrades are thrown at you. There are so many utter garbage upgrades that you pick up along the way that just clog up your inventory (even if it is limitless). -Crafting unlocks way too late in the game and only gives you upgrades based on what part of the story you are at, not based on what level your character is. You also lose access to crafting on new game+ until you reach the point in the story again that it unlocks (although due to crafting scaling to story progress it isn't worth crafting until you are at the very end of the game.) -No effective mini-map. The mini-map in this game is not very good. I wish there was a bigger version you could use to see the area as a whole that you are in and not just a slightly bigger version when you push m.  Even though I went more in depth on the negatives than the positives, I would still recommend this game to people who want a fun single player experience with lots of fast paced combat and mayhem. It can also be really fun when played with friends, but be warned of the co-op specific bugs that exist. To avoid some of the bugs, I would recommend making it known via voice chat when the host is moving since some of the bugs occur when the clients are messing around with their inventory during a teleport.

I'd still heartily recommend this one, but just be aware that it's not quite the same kind of game that the first reboot was anymore.  Pros:  -The noment to moment gameplay loop is still top notch. Melee combat is still great, and the weapons are interesting and feel good to use. Combat is still super fun and fast paced. -The story is interesting, with decent voice acting -The humor from the first game is still very present here -Sidequests add some extra fun things to do, though it makes the game feel a bit more meandering. -The game looks beautiful. Graphics are top notch.  Cons: -The borderlands-style loot system is too complex for what this game is meant to be, in my opinion. I'm here to chop up a bunch of demons, not stop very 10 seconds to vacuum up all this loot and then try to figure out whether this new '+4.5 damage, -1.5 movement speed' socket is better than the one I already have. It breaks up the action and makes the whole game feel less tight. -On a related note, the random level generator they touted is a nice idea, but in practice it made the levels feel empty sometimes, without even any enemies to fight. Entire buildings were just completely barren, with maybe only a chest sitting in the middle. It really is jarring when you compare it to the great art design of the one-of-a-kind sets they made, both in parts of this game and the last one. I honestly think I'd prefer fewer but custom designed areas, rather than this huge number of samey, empty feeling areas.

Shadow Warrior 2 takes the great sword combat and shooting from part one and adds Borderlands style collecting and upgrading, skills and also adds side missions. The upgrade system improves damage and resistance to damage and allows you to add several improvements to each of the many weapons in the game. The weapon loadout is impressive and nicely varied. Besides the many sword variants there's anything from a bow and arrow up to a nail gun. Side missions can be collected from characters in the main hub map and serve to provide skill points for unlocking and improving additional combat and support skills. Skills improve health or chi (used to power abilities) or add new abilities you can use in the game. You also collect money which you can spend in the stores to buy more upgrades (and sell the crap ones). Don't like the collectathon? Then ignore it and slice your way through your enemies the hard way. Just fit in the highest level upgrades every once in a while and you'll be fine. I personally wish I didn't have to rely so much on the minimap for finding chests and items, though. The cluttered maps sometimes make it difficult to recognise things.  The story and the writing are okay. The humor is what it is and can sometimes be funny, sometimes not. If you already played the previous game, you know what you are in for. If not, you didn't really miss out, storywise.  From the technical side you get a very well optimized game that can really look quite pretty. There are loads of settings to tweak to further improve the visuals or the frame rate. All in all Shadow Warrior 2 is a technically very competent PC title.  There's also coop, though I haven't tried that yet.  This is a solid if not perfect game that is definitely worth its asking price.
